text: satellite images from NATO of Russian
armor and advanced warplanes part the
Alliance says of a Russian military
buildup on Ukraine's eastern border to
intimidate Kiev or even to provide
Moscow with a military option Russia
says the images are old the Alliance
insists they're recent and this
potentially the next flashpoint in the
diplomatic standoff behind barricades
pro-russians occupying a government
building in eastern Ukraine the
country's interim Prime Minister is
visiting the region to try to defuse the
new tensions I would like to state
clearly the central government is not
only ready for dialogue with the regions
but is ready to fulfill the lawful
requirements and the wishes of all of
the citizens of our country whether
that'll satisfy the separatists or the
Kremlin is another matter as Kiev and
Moscow continued to blame each other for
fomenting trouble and the Russian
President Vladimir Putin has turned up
the heat in another way
warning that Russian gas supplies to
Ukraine could be cut with a potentially
serious knock-on effect elsewhere in
Europe Moscow says Ukraine owes the
Russian energy giant Gazprom some 2.2
billion dollars and it's nearly doubled
prices to Ukraine but mr. Putin has sent
his warning to 18 European countries who
rely on Russian gas imports saying their
supplies could be affected Russia
currently meets some 30 percent of
Europe's natural gas needs with about
half of that flowing through Ukraine mr.
Putin's intervention prompted this new
rebuke from Washington
we condemn Russia's efforts to use
energy as a tool of coercion against
Ukraine Ukraine is now paying 485
dollars a price clearly not set by
market forces it's all a volatile
backdrop as diplomats plan new
international talks for next week to try
to de-escalate this high-stakes standoff
Nick child's BBC news
[Music]
